Participants.evidence: patients who had miniplates placed for BAMP treatment from January 2010 to April 2020 at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Diseases, Helsinki University Hospital, Finland

Intervention.evidence: divided into two groups based on the operator: surgical residents (Group 1) and consultant surgeons (Group 2)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the failure rate of miniplates used in bone-anchored maxillary protraction (BAMP) treatment for skeletal Class III malocclusion and evaluate the impact of the surgeon's experience on the failure rate.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the failure rate of miniplates, assessed over the treatment duration.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The study group comprised 164 miniplates in 42 patients

Number_Analysed.evidence: Group 1 had a failure rate of 31.4% (27/86), while Group 2 had a failure rate of 15.3% (12/78)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The overall failure rate of miniplates was 23.8% (39/164). Group 1 had a failure rate of 31.4% (27/86), while Group 2 had a failure rate of 15.3% (12/78) (p < 0.05).
